content.description:
This line is awesome!  In the middle of the wall, at middle height is a gorgeous jug rail.  Below this are a couple of excellent pockets.  Start below and right with a good right hand side pull.  Move up to the pockets, and your off! Enjoy the ride through the mean streets of Laredo.  Classic.  

  Originally rated V1? Let me know what you think.
Pinch Overhang is hard to miss. With an hour glass shaped jug, and perfect finger pod pocket above. Move up past a finger bucket on the right, and slopey gaston jug on the left. Good holds above.

To the right of Blue Corn Sunday is a seam with a small pine tree growing out of it at the top of the wall.  This is Man of Misery.  An assortment of starting holds, and a big move will  deliver you to a good finger lock above.

climbs.name: Harriet Tubman's Gonna Carry me Home

content.description: Classically devious line of hard holds, tenuous moves, and one really big swing!! In the middle of the wall, locate a very conspicuous, flat cut undercling with another flat cut hold on top of this solid flake. This is the starting hold, and good luck to you. I found this to be a very technical and powerful line and more around the V7ish range? Classic moves once you get it figured out.
On the far left side of the wall, locate some very nice pockets. Climb straight up passing sidpulls, a crimp, and good jugs at the top. Climbs a barely there gray streak.
This is an awesome little link up of Pinch Overhang and HTGCMH. From the finger bucket crimp on Pinch Overhang, move right to large slightly sloping hold. Join HTGCMH from there.

This is a burly line, punctuated by several tiny biter crimps.  On the middle/right of the wall, find a couple of big slopers at the base of a seam. There is a large, right facing side pull directly above these slopers. Then there are the crimps. The left one is almost two finges, and maybe 5/16 on a good day.  The right one is just as skinny, but awards you two or three fingers... Choose wisely. After that, there is a perfect, positive half pad crimp right on the seam itself.  You will know what I am talking about when you see it.  Hit that, and swing up the jugs to the top. 

  Though most of the lines up here are Robert's or Flagstaff Oldschool, I had to rap this line, and delicately manicure the spines off of all three important crimps.  There would have been know way of doing the line previously.  Kudos to Joel for knocking it off in a couple heart beats.

Just to the right of A Moment of Airity, find a good left hand crimp, and another slightly worse off crimp for the right.  Move up with the left to a good sharp crimp, pinch the bulb out right, and fire up to a huge edge. 

  There are a couple of easy variations just to the right of this line.

In A Cheap Way To Fly, there is a "roof band traverse" mentioned. After looking at the large, detatched looking blocks up there, I rapped in and had a look. In short order I easily pulled of a microwave sized block with my hands. These used to be the holds!!! After some more cleaning of large loose flakes, we ended up with a fantastic dyno problem with some of the best holds on the wall.

 Start at a perfect three finger pocket crimp with the left, and another equally perfect finger bucket rail for the right. Above you and to the right is a large, deep, side pull pocket that is hard to ignore. Latch that sucker, and real in jugs to the top. Classic for the grade.
content.location: Left side of the wall, left of the tree.

pathTokens: Land of High Bouldering AKA The Ridge

content.description:
The Long Ryders Wall is a bulging crown of limestone, perforated with big deep pockets, clean crimps, joyous finger buckets and more.  Expect unique lines with plenty of deadpointing, dynoing, and gut sucking tension moves. This is certainly one of Rob's better walls out here. 

  This is a sunny wall, and you will want cool temps to enjoy it.  25-40 degrees and sunny is perfect, though a little warmer and cloudy might be easier on the eyes.
